Literature Review: Partial identification is a crucial aspect of econometrics that deals with the estimation of parameters in models where the exact value of the parameter cannot be learned from the data. This is often the case in empirical applications where the model assumptions are not fully satisfied. The literature on partial identification has made significant progress in recent years, leading to the development of various frameworks for conducting partial identification analysis. This review aims to provide an overview of the general frameworks and some of the more recent results on partial identification, with a focus on set identification, bounds, treatment effects, shape restrictions, and optimizing behavior.
